newsitem.title: USA: Utah suing federal government over wilderness move.
newsitem.headline: Utah suing federal government over wilderness move.

text.p: The state of Utah on Monday sued the (U.S.) Interior Department, claiming the federal government wants to set aside more areas for wilderness protection without adequate public consultation.
The state joined with county commissioners in filing the lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Salt Lake City.

The lawsuit claims Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt is surveying areas in Utah for wilderness designation without following the procedures outlined in a 1979 law passed by Congress, said Vicki Varela, spokeswoman for Republican Gov. Mike Leavitt.
When areas are set aside as wilderness, road building and other development are strictly limited.

Some of the state's leading politicians -- Utah Republicans Sen. Orrin Hatch, Bob Bennett, Representative Jim Hansen as well as Democratic Representative Bill Orton -- held a news conference on Monday to announce the lawsuit.
"What the Interior Department is doing now doesn't make sense and we want to have our day in court," Leavitt said. "I want to create more wilderness (areas). It's a question of the process."

Utah politicians felt left out of the process when President Bill Clinton last month announced he was creating the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, which covers 1.7 million acres (688,000 hectares) in southern Utah.
The governor is concerned that Utah school trust lands are in jeopardy because of the Interior Department's interest in those lands for wilderness designation.
In some Western states such lands have been set aside for the benefit of school districts, with funds from development of those lands going toward education.
Varela said the governor's motivation for filing the lawsuit was in part to assure that the federal government "can't take that land from the school children of Utah."
